intro: Agalinis maritima f. candida, commonly known as the white sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, white to pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils along dunes and coastal plains, thriving in well-drained, sunny environments. Its foliage consists of narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine, silky hairs. The species is notable for its ecological role in stabilizing coastal dunes and supporting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
